_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This section reflects updated information that has been developed subsequent to the June 1999 and 2004 Risk Management Plans for this facility.  The purpose of acknowledging these changes is to provide a more accurate Risk Management Plan for use by the City of Lewisville for the five-year renewal commencing June 21, 2009, and for the following five-year period.

INTRODUCTION
The United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) finalized the Accidental Release Prevention Program (ARPP) under Section 112(r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments and subsequently finalized the Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program rule (40 CFR Part 68).  This rule established the criteria of the Risk Management Plans (RMPs) required under the ARPP. 40 CFR Part 68 is similar to the Occupational Safety and Health AdministrationA?s Process Safety Management Program, which is designed to protect workers from accidental releases of hazardous substances. In compliance with the Risk Management Program requirements, Lewisville submitted Risk Management Plans (RMPA?s) to USEPA in June 1999 and in 2004 for its water and wastewater treatment facilities.

The regulations require that these RMPs be resubmitted within five years following the last submission of the plans.  In addition, while the resubmission is to reflect a general update of all sections of the risk management plans, specific elements of each plan, the Offsite Consequence Analysis and the Hazard Assessment, must be redeveloped prior to resubmission of the plans. Additionally, the regulations require that if any facilities are modified through improvements that change equipment, controls, or amount of chemical in use onsite, the risk management plans must be updated to reflect the changes. Effective April 9, 2004, the U.S. EPA issued Changes to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Risk Management Program) in 2004; these changes were incorporated into the 2004 Risk Management Plan update for the C. R. (Tommy) Fea

ster Water Production Plant for the City of Lewisville, Texas.

The C.R. Tommy Feaster Water Treatment Plant (WTP) does not fall under the Risk Management Program rule because the onsite storage of ammonia is less than the threshold quantity.  However, a RMP, modeled after 40 CFR Part 68, was generated to comply with the General Duty Clause.  The management of the C.R. Tommy Feaster WTP has complied with the USEPA General Duty Clause and has established an Accidental Release Prevention Program that contains the required information.

The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant falls under this regulation because of the onsite storage of chlorine.  The amount of chlorine stored exceeds the threshold limit specified by the USEPA, thereby making the facility subject to compliance with the regulation.  The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant personnel have complied with the USEPA Risk Management Program rule and have completed a RMP contains the following required information:
A? A management system (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart A);
A? A hazard assessment that establishes the worst-case and alternative release scenarios and their impacts on the population and the environment (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart B);
A? A prevention program that includes safety information, a hazard review, operating procedures, training, maintenance, compliance audits, and incident investigations (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart C); and
A? An emergency response plan (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart E).
The following subsections discuss details of the plan that has been implemented at the C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant.

RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production facility in Lewisville, Texas has an excellent record in preventing and minimizing releases of chlorine and ammonia.  The emergency response policies at this facility ensure that there is emergency response coverage 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  Adequate provisions have been impleme

nted to coordinate response activities with outside agencies, such as the City of Lewisville Fire Department in case of an emergency. The plant staff will receive training to enable an on-site staff response prior to the arrival of either the City of Irving HAZMAT Team or the City of Lewisville HAZMAT Team.  The City of Irving HAZMAT Team will respond to a major release while the City of Lewisville HAZMAT Team will respond to a minor release.

REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant uses chlorine and ammonia as part of the disinfection process of water production. Chlorine is used in quantities that exceed the threshold limit set by the USEPA.

PROCESS DESCRIPTION
The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant is located at 1400 N. Cowan Avenue, in Lewisville, Texas and draws its raw water supply from Lake Lewisville.  The raw water is treated at the plant and subsequently pumped to the distribution network of pipelines, pump stations, and storage tanks.  

The existing chlorine feed facility at the C. R. Tommy Feaster WTP consists of an enclosed storage area, two vacuum regulators mounted to a manual switchover module with gas piping and miscellaneous valves and drip lines, three flow proportionate feed chlorinators, and gas piping and ejectors. A release of chlorine gas could potentially occur at the chlorine storage area or at the chlorine process areas.  Chlorine is removed as a gas in a pressure feed system, however, the majority of the chlorine feed system is operated through a water injection induced vacuum, making the system extremely safe and minimizing potential pressurized leaks along the feed lines.  In addition, the storage room is equipped with a scrubber, in order to neutralize possible leaks from the system.
The existing ammonia feed facility at the C.R. Tommy Feaster WTP consists of storage tanks, two manual feed ammoniators, and gas piping and ejectors. The potential to generate a release of ammonia gas exists at the

storage and process area.  

WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
The chlorine and ammonia storage and process areas have associated hazards that can potentially affect onsite employees and the offsite population and environment.  The USEPA requires that a single worst-case release scenario for the facility and one alternative release scenario for each regulated chemical be reported. 

Worst-Case Release Scenario
A worst case release scenario was developed for this update.  However, in accordance with guidance from EPAA?s April 9, 2004 regulation modification to 2004 RMP updates, this information is intentionally omitted from this Executive Summary.

Alternative Release Scenario
An alternative release scenario was developed for this update.  However, in accordance with guidance from EPAA?s April 9, 2004 regulation modification to 2004 RMP updates, this information is intentionally omitted from this Executive Summary.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant carries out consistent operation and maintenance of its chlorine and ammonia equipment utilizing only fully trained personnel in this area.  The C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant management enforces consistent operation through discipline for operational deviations.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The accident history for the C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant was reviewed for a period from June 2004 through June 2009.  During this period of time, no accidental releases of chlorine or ammonia had occurred.  

Policies were developed by the City of Lewisville that will cause a resubmission of the RMP within six months of the occurrence of a reportable chlorine or ammonia release.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The City of Lewisville has developed an Emergency Response Program in which plant employees are divided into various management and response teams.  Back-up personnel are available in the event that the primary response personnel ca

nnot be contacted. 

The Emergency Response Plan includes: (1) procedures to follow in the event of a chlorine and/or ammonia emergency; (2) information about frequency of employee emergency response training, and (3) a detailed description of the emergency response training underway. Emergency responders and equipment will be provided by either the City of Irving HAZMAT Team or the City of Lewisville HAZMAT Team; the HAZMAT Team will assume Incident Command upon arrival to the plant.

Policies were developed by the City of Lewisville that will cause a correction submission for the RMP for any emergency contact information changes within 30 days of the change.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
A? Based on the hazard review and prevention evaluation completed for chlorine and ammonia in 2009, a list of action items was developed and is planned to be considered over the next five years in conjunction with anticipated improvements to be made at the C. R. (Tommy) Feaster Water Production Plant.
